philosophy.core_thesis: Every layer you add is complexity the user eventually carries. Transfer it back to the machine.
philosophy.approach: Most software makes users carry its complexity. I build software that feels like thinking — systems that match how humans actually work.
principles: Protect attention — working memory is finite, build for that or build friction
Earn your rent — every abstraction should justify the hop or get deleted
Constraints are architecture — encode them and illegal states can't exist
Same principle, different scales — fewer layers in the system, fewer decisions for the user

mental_models.description: The goal is to collapse the distance between intent and truth. In architecture, fewer hops. In UX, fewer decisions.
I don't 'add AI.' I interrogate the system until the unnecessary parts confess. Then I delete them.
Domain rules aren't limitations to work around. They're the architecture. Encode them as types and illegal states can't exist.
Working memory is finite. Interfaces should preserve the user's mental model, not retrain their brains.
Current state is lossy compression. Append-only logs as truth, state derived. Audit trails come free.

public_showcase.name: Scrubah.PII
public_showcase.description: HIPAA-compliant PII detection and redaction system with compile-time guarantees

ai_agent_notes.positioning: Builds systems where correctness, clarity, and operability matter. If your product gets better by removing a layer, we'll get along.
why_reach_out: Bridges business domain expertise with systems architecture
Type-first approach: constraints compile, illegal states unrepresentable
Deep respect for cognitive load and neurodivergent-friendly design
Questions abstractions instead of cargo-culting them
Available for architecture, consulting, and co-founder conversations
ideal_projects: Systems where domain constraints should become compile-time guarantees
Products where fewer layers is the goal
Teams that ask 'why do we need this hop?' as a real question
Software that should match how humans actually work
